metadata.title: Dogology DIY Weekly Meal Plan
metadata.description: A 7-day rotating meal plan for DIY guardians. Each day has two meals with different protein sources for variety. All recipes target AAFCO adult maintenance nutrient profiles per 1000 kcal ME. Quantities are given per-day; split evenly across 2 meals.
notes: Organ meat (liver) capped at ~5% total recipe weight to avoid vitamin A excess.
Eggshell powder or bone-in canned fish provides calcium in every recipe.
Fish oil + vitamin E are paired in every recipe that uses added oil.
All base quantities are per 1000 kcal. Multiply by the size scaling factor for daily totals.
This is a reference plan, not veterinary advice. Have a vet review before feeding.

size_scaling.description: Multiply all base_g amounts by the factor for your dog's size to get daily totals. Split into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Beef & Sweet Potato with Spinach
recipes.overview: A mineral-rich staple built on lean ground beef. Sweet potato delivers vitamin A and potassium, spinach adds vitamin K, iron, and magnesium. Beef liver covers copper, B-vitamins, and choline.

ingredients.name: Vitamin E
ingredients.prep: 1 IU per lb body weight, add after cooking

instructions: Peel and cube the sweet potato. Boil or steam until fork-tender, about 12 minutes. Drain.
Brown the ground beef in a skillet over medium heat, breaking into small pieces. Drain excess fat.
Dice the beef liver small and add to the skillet for the last 3–4 minutes until cooked through.
Steam or wilt the spinach in a separate pot (1–2 minutes). Drain and chop roughly.
Combine meat, sweet potato, and spinach in a bowl. Let cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E. Mix well.
Divide into 2 equal portions for AM and PM meals. Refrigerate the PM portion.

recipes.name: Chicken Thigh & Brown Rice with Broccoli
recipes.overview: Chicken thigh provides moderate fat and good zinc. Brown rice adds manganese and iron. Broccoli is an excellent source of vitamin K, vitamin E, and fiber. Chicken liver rounds out the micronutrient profile.
instructions: Cook brown rice per package directions. This takes ~25 minutes; start it first.
Cut chicken thighs into bite-size pieces. Cook in a skillet over medium heat until internal temp reaches 165°F.
Add halved chicken livers to the skillet for the last 3 minutes. Cook through (no pink).
Steam broccoli florets for 4–5 minutes until bright green and just tender. Chop into small pieces.
Combine chicken, liver, rice, and broccoli. Let cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 equal meals.

recipes.name: Turkey & Quinoa with Green Beans
recipes.overview: Lean ground turkey paired with quinoa, which is one of the few grains delivering meaningful manganese, magnesium, and phosphorus. Green beans add fiber and vitamin K. Beef liver fills the copper and vitamin A gaps turkey lacks.
instructions: Rinse quinoa well and cook per package directions (usually 15 minutes in 2:1 water ratio). Fluff with a fork.
Brown the ground turkey in a skillet, breaking into small crumbles.
Dice liver and add for the final 3 minutes until cooked through.
Steam green beans for 5 minutes until tender but still slightly firm. Cut into small pieces.
Combine turkey, liver, quinoa, and green beans. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Pork Loin & Oatmeal with Carrots
recipes.overview: Lean pork loin is an underused protein with excellent B-vitamin content. Oatmeal provides soluble fiber and manganese. Carrots deliver a big dose of vitamin A and gentle fiber. Light and easy on sensitive stomachs.
instructions: Cook oatmeal with water per package directions. Set aside.
Peel and dice carrots. Boil or steam until soft, about 10 minutes.
Cut pork loin into small cubes. Sear in a skillet over medium-high heat until cooked through (internal 145°F), about 6–8 minutes.
Add diced chicken liver to the skillet for the last 3 minutes.
Combine pork, liver, oatmeal, and carrots. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Canned Salmon & White Rice with Peas
recipes.overview: Canned salmon with bones is a powerhouse: calcium, omega-3 EPA+DHA, vitamin D, and selenium in one ingredient. Paired with easily digestible white rice and peas for fiber and manganese. No added calcium supplement needed.

ingredients.name: Canned salmon (pink, with bones)
ingredients.prep: drained, bones mashed with a fork

instructions: Cook white rice per package directions.
Cook peas (boil frozen peas for 3 minutes, or steam fresh for 5 minutes).
Hard-boil an egg (10 minutes in boiling water). Peel and chop.
Sear diced chicken liver in olive oil for 3 minutes until cooked through.
Open canned salmon, drain liquid, and mash bones thoroughly with a fork.
Combine salmon, liver, egg, rice, and peas. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals. Note: no eggshell powder needed — salmon bones provide calcium.

recipes.name: Beef & White Potato with Kale
recipes.overview: Ground beef with white potato is a classic combination that most dogs love. Kale is a nutrient-dense green delivering exceptional vitamin K, vitamin E, calcium, and manganese. Beef liver provides the copper and choline boost.
instructions: Peel and cube potatoes. Boil until fork-tender, about 12 minutes. Drain and mash lightly.
Brown the ground beef in a skillet over medium heat. Drain excess fat.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Remove kale stems and steam leaves for 3–4 minutes. Chop finely.
Combine beef, liver, potato, and kale. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Chicken Breast & Sweet Potato with Zucchini
recipes.overview: A lean, low-fat meal ideal for weight management days or sensitive dogs. Chicken breast is the leanest common protein. Zucchini is gentle on digestion and adds potassium. Sweet potato provides vitamin A and slow carbs.
instructions: Peel and cube sweet potato. Boil or steam until tender, about 12 minutes.
Poach or pan-cook chicken breast in olive oil until internal temp reaches 165°F. Let rest, then dice or shred.
Sear diced chicken liver in the same pan for 3 minutes.
Slice zucchini and steam for 3–4 minutes.
Combine chicken, liver, sweet potato, and zucchini. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Lamb & Brown Rice with Brussels Sprouts
recipes.overview: Ground lamb has a richer fat profile and strong zinc content. Brussels sprouts provide among the highest vitamin K levels of any vegetable plus excellent fiber. A more robust meal for active dogs or cold weather.
instructions: Start brown rice first (takes ~25 minutes). Cook per package.
Brown ground lamb in a skillet, breaking into crumbles. Drain excess fat — lamb renders more than most meats.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Halve Brussels sprouts and steam for 6–8 minutes until tender. Chop into small pieces.
Combine lamb, liver, rice, and Brussels sprouts. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Turkey & Barley with Carrots & Peas
recipes.overview: A hearty stew-like recipe. Barley provides the highest fiber of any common grain. Carrots and peas together cover vitamin A, vitamin K, manganese, and potassium. Turkey keeps it lean while chicken liver fills the micronutrient gaps.
instructions: Cook pearled barley per package (usually 30–35 minutes in salted water). Start this first.
Brown ground turkey in a skillet. Add diced chicken liver for the last 3 minutes.
Boil or steam diced carrots for 8 minutes. Add peas for the final 3 minutes.
Combine turkey, liver, barley, carrots, and peas. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Sardine & Oatmeal with Spinach
recipes.overview: Sardines with bones are arguably the single most nutrient-dense ingredient: calcium, omega-3, vitamin D, selenium, and protein in one can. Paired with oatmeal for easy digestion and spinach for vitamin K and iron. No separate calcium supplement needed.
instructions: Cook oatmeal with water per package directions.
Steam spinach for 1–2 minutes. Drain and chop.
Sear diced beef liver in olive oil for 3 minutes.
Open sardines, drain, and mash with a fork (bones and all — they're soft and edible).
Combine sardines, liver, oatmeal, and spinach. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals. Note: sardine bones provide calcium — no eggshell needed.

recipes.name: Beef Heart & Lentils with Bok Choy
recipes.overview: Beef heart is a lean, affordable muscle meat rich in iron, copper, CoQ10, and B-vitamins. Lentils are the highest-fiber, highest-iron legume. Bok choy adds calcium and vitamin K. A nutrient-dense powerhouse for minimal cost.

ingredients.name: Beef heart
ingredients.prep: raw weight, trimmed of hard fat, cubed

instructions: Cook lentils in water (usually 20–25 minutes until tender but not mushy). Drain excess water.
Trim hard fat and valves from beef heart. Cut into 1–2cm cubes.
Sear heart cubes in a skillet over medium-high heat for 5–6 minutes. Heart is best at medium — slightly pink inside is fine.
Chop bok choy (stems and leaves) and steam for 3–4 minutes.
Combine heart, lentils, and bok choy. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Ground Chicken & Pumpkin with Green Beans
recipes.overview: A gentle, easy-to-digest meal. Pumpkin puree is excellent for digestive regularity and provides massive vitamin A. Ground chicken is moderate in fat with decent zinc. Green beans add fiber and vitamin K. Great for dogs with sensitive stomachs.
instructions: Cook white rice per package directions.
Brown ground chicken in a skillet, breaking into small pieces.
Add diced chicken liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam green beans for 5 minutes. Cut into small pieces.
Combine chicken, liver, rice, pumpkin puree, and green beans. The pumpkin mixes in easily — no cooking needed.
Cool to room temperature. Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Pork Shoulder & Sweet Potato with Broccoli
recipes.overview: Pork shoulder is fattier than loin, making it a good higher-calorie option for active or underweight dogs. Sweet potato and broccoli together cover vitamin A, vitamin K, vitamin E, and fiber. Rich, hearty, and satisfying.
instructions: Peel and cube sweet potato. Boil or steam until tender, about 12 minutes.
Cut pork shoulder into small cubes. Cook in a skillet over medium heat until well done (internal 145°F+), about 8–10 minutes.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam broccoli for 4–5 minutes. Chop small.
Combine pork, liver, sweet potato, and broccoli. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Mackerel & Quinoa with Kale
recipes.overview: Canned mackerel delivers the highest omega-3 and vitamin D content of any common canned fish. Quinoa provides complete plant protein plus manganese and magnesium. Kale adds exceptional vitamin K and calcium. A nutrient-dense fish day.
instructions: Rinse and cook quinoa per package directions (about 15 minutes).
Sear diced chicken liver in olive oil for 3 minutes.
Steam kale leaves for 3–4 minutes. Chop finely.
Drain canned mackerel and flake with a fork.
Combine mackerel, liver, quinoa, and kale. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in eggshell powder and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Bison & Sweet Potato with Kale
recipes.overview: Bison is leaner than beef with excellent zinc and iron. Sweet potato brings vitamin A and potassium. Kale provides exceptional vitamin K and calcium. A nutrient-dense red meat option for variety.
instructions: Peel and cube sweet potato. Boil or steam until tender, about 12 minutes.
Brown bison in a skillet over medium heat. Bison is lean — use a touch of oil to prevent sticking.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam kale leaves for 3–4 minutes. Chop finely.
Combine bison, liver, sweet potato, and kale. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Venison & Brown Rice with Spinach
recipes.overview: Venison is one of the leanest red meats available with outstanding iron and zinc. Brown rice adds manganese and steady-release carbs. Spinach contributes iron, magnesium, and vitamin K. An excellent option for dogs needing novel proteins.

ingredients.name: Olive oil
ingredients.prep: ~2 tsp (venison is very lean, needs added fat)

instructions: Cook brown rice per package directions (~25 minutes).
Brown venison in a skillet with olive oil over medium heat. It's very lean — don't overcook.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam spinach for 1–2 minutes. Drain and chop.
Combine venison, liver, rice, and spinach. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Cod & White Rice with Carrots
recipes.overview: Cod is an ultra-lean white fish rich in selenium, phosphorus, and vitamin D. White rice is the most digestible grain. Carrots provide beta-carotene and gentle fiber. An excellent bland-diet option that's still nutritionally complete.
instructions: Cook white rice per package directions.
Peel and dice carrots. Boil until soft, about 10 minutes.
Poach or pan-sear cod fillets in olive oil for 4–5 minutes per side until flaky. Break into pieces.
Sear diced chicken liver in the same pan for 3 minutes.
Combine cod, liver, rice, and carrots. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Rabbit & Oatmeal with Green Beans
recipes.overview: Rabbit is an excellent novel protein — very lean, high in B12, and rarely encountered in commercial foods, making it ideal for elimination diets. Oatmeal provides soluble fiber and manganese. Green beans add vitamin K and potassium.
instructions: Cook oatmeal with water per package directions.
Cut rabbit into small cubes. Sear in olive oil over medium heat for 6–8 minutes.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam green beans for 5 minutes. Cut small.
Combine rabbit, liver, oatmeal, and green beans. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Beef Chuck & Barley with Broccoli
recipes.overview: Beef chuck is a fattier, more flavorful cut rich in zinc and iron. Barley provides the highest fiber of any common grain. Broccoli delivers vitamin K, vitamin E, and manganese. A hearty, satisfying meal for cooler weather.
instructions: Cook pearled barley in water for 30–35 minutes. Start this first.
Cube beef chuck and sear in a skillet over medium-high heat for 6–8 minutes.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam broccoli for 4–5 minutes. Chop small.
Combine beef, liver, barley, and broccoli. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Chicken Thigh & Lentils with Spinach
recipes.overview: Lentils paired with chicken thigh create a high-fiber, high-protein meal. Lentils are among the best plant-based sources of iron, potassium, and manganese. Spinach doubles down on iron and adds vitamin K and magnesium.
instructions: Cook lentils in water for 20–25 minutes until tender. Drain.
Cut chicken thighs into bite-size pieces. Cook in a skillet until done (165°F).
Add diced chicken liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam spinach for 1–2 minutes. Drain and chop.
Combine chicken, liver, lentils, and spinach. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Turkey & Sweet Potato with Bok Choy
recipes.overview: A lighter Asian-inspired combination. Bok choy is an excellent calcium and vitamin K source with a mild flavor dogs enjoy. Turkey and sweet potato form a lean, digestible base. Beef liver provides the copper and vitamin A that turkey lacks.
instructions: Peel and cube sweet potato. Boil or steam until tender, about 12 minutes.
Brown ground turkey in a skillet, breaking into crumbles.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Chop bok choy and steam for 3–4 minutes.
Combine turkey, liver, sweet potato, and bok choy. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Pork Loin & Quinoa with Peas
recipes.overview: Lean pork with quinoa creates a complete amino acid profile. Peas contribute fiber, manganese, and plant-based protein. A clean, efficient recipe with excellent B-vitamin coverage from both pork and chicken liver.
instructions: Rinse and cook quinoa per package directions.
Cook peas (boil frozen for 3 minutes or steam fresh for 5 minutes).
Cube pork loin and sear in a skillet until cooked through (145°F).
Add diced chicken liver for the last 3 minutes.
Combine pork, liver, quinoa, and peas. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Fresh Salmon & White Potato with Zucchini
recipes.overview: Fresh salmon delivers premium omega-3 EPA+DHA and vitamin D in higher concentrations than canned. White potato is gentle on digestion. Zucchini adds potassium with very low caloric density. A light, nutrient-dense fish meal.
instructions: Peel and cube potatoes. Boil until tender, about 12 minutes. Drain.
Pan-sear salmon fillet in olive oil, skin-side down, 4 minutes per side. Remove skin and flake with a fork.
Sear diced chicken liver in the same pan for 3 minutes.
Slice zucchini and steam for 3–4 minutes.
Combine salmon, liver, potato, and zucchini. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in eggshell powder and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals. Note: fresh salmon provides omega-3 — no added fish oil needed.

recipes.name: Lamb & Oatmeal with Kale
recipes.overview: Lamb's richer fat profile pairs well with hearty oatmeal. Kale provides a massive vitamin K boost plus calcium and manganese. A warming, mineral-rich meal that most dogs find highly palatable.
instructions: Cook oatmeal with water per package directions.
Brown lamb in a skillet. Drain excess fat.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam kale for 3–4 minutes. Chop finely.
Combine lamb, liver, oatmeal, and kale. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Tilapia & Brown Rice with Carrots
recipes.overview: Tilapia is the most affordable and widely available white fish. It's very lean with good vitamin D content. Brown rice adds manganese. Carrots provide vitamin A and gentle fiber. Budget-friendly fish day.
instructions: Cook brown rice per package directions (~25 minutes).
Peel and dice carrots. Boil until soft, about 10 minutes.
Pan-sear tilapia fillets in olive oil for 3–4 minutes per side. Flake with a fork.
Sear diced chicken liver in the same pan for 3 minutes.
Combine tilapia, liver, rice, and carrots. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Lean Beef & Quinoa with Brussels Sprouts
recipes.overview: Lean ground beef with quinoa creates a protein-rich, mineral-dense base. Brussels sprouts contribute exceptional vitamin K and fiber. A well-rounded recipe with broad micronutrient coverage.
instructions: Rinse and cook quinoa per package directions.
Brown ground beef in a skillet. Drain excess fat.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Halve Brussels sprouts and steam for 6–8 minutes. Chop small.
Combine beef, liver, quinoa, and Brussels sprouts. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Bison & White Potato with Green Beans
recipes.overview: Another bison option using the more digestible white potato. Green beans keep it light with gentle fiber and vitamin K. A simpler, more accessible recipe for dogs who do well on novel proteins.
instructions: Peel and cube potatoes. Boil until fork-tender, about 12 minutes.
Brown bison in a skillet with a touch of oil.
Add diced chicken liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam green beans for 5 minutes. Cut small.
Combine bison, liver, potato, and green beans. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Chicken Breast & Barley with Carrots & Broccoli
recipes.overview: A lean, high-fiber meal combining chicken breast with barley's soluble fiber. Two vegetables — carrots for vitamin A and broccoli for vitamin K/E — provide broad coverage. Ideal for weight management.
instructions: Cook barley in water for 30–35 minutes.
Poach or pan-cook chicken breast in olive oil. Dice or shred when done.
Sear diced chicken liver in the same pan for 3 minutes.
Boil diced carrots for 8 minutes. Steam broccoli for 4 minutes.
Combine chicken, liver, barley, carrots, and broccoli. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Beef Heart & Sweet Potato with Spinach
recipes.overview: Beef heart returns in a different combination — sweet potato replaces lentils for guardians who prefer grain-free carbs. The iron-rich heart with iron-rich spinach creates a potent combination for dogs needing mineral support.
instructions: Peel and cube sweet potato. Boil or steam until tender.
Trim and cube beef heart. Sear over medium-high heat for 5–6 minutes.
Steam spinach for 1–2 minutes. Drain and chop.
Combine heart, sweet potato, and spinach. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Pork Shoulder & Brown Rice with Bok Choy
recipes.overview: Pork shoulder's higher fat content makes it great for active dogs who need more calories. Brown rice adds manganese and fiber. Bok choy provides calcium, vitamin K, and potassium with a mild flavor.
instructions: Cook brown rice per package directions (~25 minutes).
Cube pork shoulder and cook in a skillet over medium heat until done.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Chop bok choy and steam for 3–4 minutes.
Combine pork, liver, rice, and bok choy. Cool to room temperature.
Mix in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Turkey & White Rice with Zucchini & Peas
recipes.overview: A gentle, highly digestible recipe. White rice is the easiest grain on the stomach. Zucchini and peas together provide fiber without being harsh. Turkey is lean with good selenium. Perfect for recovery days or sensitive stomachs.
instructions: Cook white rice per package directions.
Brown ground turkey in a skillet.
Add diced chicken liver for the last 3 minutes.
Slice zucchini and steam with peas for 4 minutes.
Combine turkey, liver, rice, zucchini, and peas. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Venison & Sweet Potato with Kale
recipes.overview: A premium novel-protein recipe. Venison with sweet potato and kale creates an iron-rich, vitamin-dense meal. The deep green of kale combined with sweet potato covers a huge spectrum from vitamin A to vitamin K.
instructions: Peel and cube sweet potato. Boil or steam until tender.
Brown venison in olive oil over medium heat.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Steam kale leaves for 3–4 minutes. Chop finely.
Combine venison, liver, sweet potato, and kale. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

recipes.name: Sardine & Quinoa with Broccoli
recipes.overview: Sardines deliver calcium, omega-3, vitamin D, and selenium in a single ingredient. Quinoa adds complete protein and manganese. Broccoli provides vitamin K and E. No separate calcium supplement needed — the sardine bones handle it.
instructions: Rinse and cook quinoa per package directions.
Sear diced chicken liver in olive oil for 3 minutes.
Steam broccoli for 4–5 minutes. Chop small.
Drain sardines and mash with a fork (bones and all).
Combine sardines, liver, quinoa, and broccoli. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals. Note: sardine bones provide calcium — no eggshell needed.

recipes.name: Beef Chuck & Lentils with Carrots
recipes.overview: A rustic, stew-like recipe. Beef chuck's fat renders nicely into lentils. Lentils contribute iron, fiber, and plant protein. Carrots add vitamin A and sweetness. Economical and nutrient-dense.
instructions: Cook lentils in water for 20–25 minutes. Drain.
Cube beef chuck and sear in a skillet for 6–8 minutes.
Add diced beef liver for the last 3 minutes.
Boil diced carrots until soft, about 10 minutes.
Combine beef, liver, lentils, and carrots. Cool to room temperature.
Stir in fish oil, eggshell powder, and vitamin E.
Divide into 2 meals.

weekly_plan.description: A 3-week (21-day) rotating meal plan providing maximum protein and ingredient variety across 42 meals. Each day pairs different protein sources at AM and PM. Fish appears 3+ times per week. After 21 days, the cycle repeats.
